title: Quiz 4: Disaster Phases & Health Impacts
description: Test knowledge on the chronological phases of a disaster and its impact on public health systems.

questions.question: Order the Phases of Disaster chronologically:
questions.explanation: The order is: Pre-emergency -> Impact/Flight -> Acute -> Post emergency -> Repatriation -> Rehabilitation.
questions.hint: Start before the event and end with returning home.

questions.question: Which phase ends when the crude death rate falls below 1/10,000 persons per day?
questions.explanation: The Acute phase is marked by intense activities to keep people alive and ends when mortality rates drop below 1/10,000 per day.
questions.hint: The phase with the highest death rate.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ phase involves the full resumption of socioeconomic activities and preventive measures, shifting focus from relief to development.
questions.explanation: Reconstruction/Rehabilitation is the phase where full socioeconomic activities resume.
questions.hint: It starts with 'R' and focuses on development.

questions.question: Which of the following are Public Health consequences of disasters? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Disasters typically degrade sanitation, damage health systems, worsen chronic illness, and increase pests.

questions.question: The 'Impact and Flight' phase lasts the exact same amount of time for every type of disaster.
questions.explanation: The duration depends on the type of disaster (e.g., hurricane vs drought) and the number of people affected.
questions.hint: Does a flood last as long as a drought?

questions.question: Match the disaster phase with its characteristic:

pairs.right: Priority is to keep affected people alive; intense humanitarian activity
Population movement slows; critical services established
Displaced people return to place of origin

questions.hint: Match the timing to the activity.

questions.question: During the 'Post emergency phase', international support often declines and emphasis shifts to:

options.text: Building local capacity and community participation

questions.explanation: As emergency aid fades, local capacity building becomes the priority in the post-emergency phase.
questions.hint: Who takes over when internationals leave?

questions.question: What is the term for the phase marked by the restoration of basic social functions?
questions.explanation: Rehabilitation is the restoration of basic social functions.

questions.question: Which phase involves 'Search and Rescue' and providing transportation/shelter to reduce loss of lives immediately upon disaster strike?
questions.explanation: Impact and Flight phase is when the disaster strikes and immediate rescue/flight occurs.

questions.question: Toxic hazardous exposure is a possible public health consequence of disasters.
questions.explanation: Yes, disasters can damage industrial sites leading to toxic exposures.
questions.hint: Can chemicals spill during an earthquake?
